A call to bear the burden, and to rise beyond our pains.

The meek met fire in his gaze, the proud, a shattering roar;
He promised not a gentle path, but a threshold to restore:
A world unmasked by holy strife, the falsehoods cut away—
On the scene came Christ The Lord, and night gave birth to day.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once, 
Low to the loam, spine curled in dust,
Tongue tasting the iron of earth,
Hands clutching what little was just.
My shadow folded into roots,
A hunger gnawed in hollow bones,
I learned the language of small things—
The whimper, the crawl, the groan.

But one dawn the crows called my name,
And light pierced the cage of my chest.
I rose on trembling, splintered limbs—
A prayer, a promise, a quest.
Now I walk upright with the wind,
The soil still stains my skin,
But I carry the sky in my gaze,
And refuse to bow again.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Back bent beneath the burden of my own silence,
Mouth pressed to the cold, indifferent ground.
I mistook humility for hunger and chewed my own shadow,
Fingers muddy with apology, knees aching for permission.

But time, that secret architect, built a stairway in my spine.
I learned to stand, not in defiance, but in quiet certainty.
Now I wear my past as a weathered jacket—
It fits, but no longer constrains.
I greet the dawn not as supplicant, but as kin,
And walk forth unafraid to meet the sun.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
My belly pressed to gravel, lips full of sand.
The world loomed above, a storm I could not read,
Each drop a drumbeat on my hunched, shivering back.

From darkness, I nursed bitter seeds—
Worms for hope, stones for dreams—
And in the thick of root and rot, I learned the taste of longing.

But somewhere, a flicker—
Not a blaze, but a blade of light split the grime.
I rose, slow as moss, feeling the ache of bones long bent.
Now I walk, carrying both mud and memory,
No longer crawling, but not quite flying—
Risen, but never forgetting the earth that held me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
My frame curled in supplication to the cold,
Whispering apologies to the beetles and the moss.
Rainwater pooled in the hollow of my back, and I
Clung to roots, uncertain if they held me down or tethered me in place.

Yet, I listened to the patient hum of stones,
And found, in their stillness, a promise:
One day, the spine would unfurl, the voice would rise,
And the world would meet my gaze.

So now, standing, I carry the memory of earth
In the arch of my foot, the strength of having crawled,
And the wild, upward yearning of something once small.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Lichen-hearted, pressed to the underbelly of stones,
My voice a mere shiver among root-tangles,
Dreaming only of dampness and the pale gleam of worms.

Night draped me in velvet secrecy, my eyes
Luminous pearls rolling in the socket of hunger.
But the moon, sly and full of riddles,
Whispered courage into the marrow of my crawl.

So I gathered the shimmer of dew on my back,
And with a trembling gasp, unfurled—
Not in a leap but a slow, deliberate uncoiling,
Until I stood, vertebrae by vertebrae, in the wild new light.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
Beneath the shroud of midnight air,  
My soul, in silence, makes her moan,  
And lifts to Thee a trembling prayer.  
No idol voice, no sculpted stone,  
Can answer in my hour of need;  
Thy presence, living and unknown,  
Is bread upon which spirits feed.  
Upon the winds, Thy whispers roam,  
Within the shadows, still, I see  
A spark that guides me gently home—  
O God! Thou art my God to me.  
In solitude, my heart is drawn  
To seek Thy face, to know Thy light;  
With every breath, at every dawn,  
I find Thee waiting through the night.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
No other voice can reach my ear,  
When midnight leaves me lost and prone,  
I know Thy presence lingers near.  
My heart, once tethered to the dust,  
Now soars on wings of silent trust.  
No golden calf, no temple throne,  
Could rival love that Thou hast shown.  
The world may shift, the stars may fade,  
Yet steadfast is Thy hand, Thy aid.  
Within the shadow, in the stone,  
Thy whisper carves my soul’s own tone.  
I wander, but am not alone—  
O God! Thou art my God alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
Above the storm, beyond the sea,  
When every hope and friend has flown,  
Still, in the hush, I turn to Thee.  
No earthly crown, no fleeting light,  
Can fill the hollow of my soul;  
In boundless dark or burning bright,  
Thou art the fire that makes me whole.  
In desert years, in silent pain,  
My spirit thirsts for what is Thine—  
A drop of mercy, gentle rain,  
A glimpse of love, a light, a sign.  
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
To Thee I cling, to Thee I run—  
In every shadow, every stone,  
I find my solace in the One.

O God! Thou art my God alone;  
When mountains fall and rivers freeze,  
Still, in the hollow of Thy throne,  
My restless heart finds quiet ease.  
The world dissolves in shifting sand,  
But Thou remainest, firm and true;  
No sculpted idol, made by hand,  
Could claim the love I owe to You.  
When hope is thin and night is long,  
Thy voice becomes my only song.  
In fevered dreams or fields unknown,  
I call, I seek, I yearn, I groan—  
Yet in the silence, Thou art near:  
My God, my God, I will not fear.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;  
No echo fills the empty hall,  
No golden mask, no priestly tone,  
Can answer when the shadows fall.  
Upon the wild and wind-worn stone,  
I kneel—my heart, a trembling reed—  
To whisper secrets, all my own,  
And plant the smallest, sacred seed.  
The world may whirl in fevered chase,  
With banners bright and idols proud,  
But in the hush, I seek Thy face—  
A single soul, unbowed, unbowed.  
O God! Alone, I find my place:  
Thy voice, the silence in the crowd.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears, draped in the velvet of small comforts,
Are often slow to gather your trembling notes.
You perch in the hush between heartbeats, asking—
Do I dare unclasp the locks of certainty?
Sometimes I drown you beneath laughter’s easy tide,
Sometimes I cradle you in the hollow of midnight’s hand.
But if I wake, if I gather the hush into my ribcage,
You will come, not with thunder, but with a feather’s weight,
And I—if I have learned the patience of waiting—
Will let you settle, gentle as dawn upon my tongue.
Then, only then, will I speak you—not as a weapon,
But as a lamp, carried trembling through the bracken night.
So teach me, truth, to listen: to the wind’s confession,
To the hush before words, to the ache after lies.
Let me be a vessel, empty of all but your echo,
That I may speak you, not out of vanity, but of habit,
A habit born of the hard, bright work of listening.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my tongue is restless and my mind a noisy sea.
I cup my ear for whispers that slip through morning dew,
Yet I am distracted by the clamor of what I wish to see.

You stand in the margins, patient and severe,
Waiting for me to hush my practiced explanations,
To sift the silver from the static, to draw you near,
And taste the salt of honest revelations.

Let me cultivate silence, let it bloom in my chest,
So when you knock, I am not too busy to hear.
Let me practice humility, patience, and rest,
For only then will your message appear.

Truth! I shall speak you, but first I must learn
To listen—not to my longing, but to your fragile burn.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how often do I hush the world’s clatter for your quiet tread?
You slip, barefoot, through the alleyways of my mind,
Whispering wisdom in riddles I seldom pause to decode.

I confess, too easily I barter your clarity for comfort,
My voice rehearsing the easier script, the practiced refrain.
But sometimes—on a sleepless wind, or in the hush before dawn—
I hear you, raw and relentless, threading through my doubts.

Oh, let me make a practice of silence, of waiting,
Let me learn the sacred patience to harbor your flame.
Then, when I open my mouth, may your syllables fall true:
Not borrowed, not bent, but born from the listening.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Yet my days are crowded with echoes from other tongues.
You wait, a lantern in the shadowed hallway of thought,
Soft-footed, persistent, lighting the untraveled rooms.

I stumble by, distracted by the music of certainty,
But sometimes, in the hush between questions,
Your voice rings out—a bell, clear and unadorned.

If I could only pause, unlace the armor of assumption,
And tune my heart to the subtle key of humility,
Perhaps I would hear you more often, more whole.
Then, my words would be your reflection,
Spoken not in habit, but in honest recognition.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
Yet, how readily I mistake my own longing for your voice!
You wait at the threshold of quiet, a guest I seldom invite,
Yet you linger, persistent, in the folds of my reluctance.

I chase after stories, weave comfort from half-remembered dreams,
But you, patient as stone, await my unguarded attention.
If I could unlearn the reflex to fill silences with noise,
Perhaps I would glimpse you—naked, unadorned—in the stillness.

So let me practice a listening that is more than waiting to speak,
Let me harvest humility from the fields of uncertainty.
When I finally greet you, let my words not betray your shape,
But echo your presence, clear as morning after rain.
